reference: Volume Five, Issue Forty-Five, File 5 of 28
title: A Guide to Internet Security: Becoming an Uebercracker and Becoming an UeberAdmin to stop Uebercrackers
short_summary: This article provides a humorous yet insightful guide on how to become a 'uebercracker'—an elite hacker—and how to counter such threats as an administrator. It outlines steps for both aspiring hackers and security professionals.
summary: The article is divided into two parts: the first part details 15 steps to becoming a uebercracker, a term coined by Dan Farmer to describe elite hackers who are nearly impossible to keep out of networks. The steps include familiarizing oneself with Unix commands, engaging in IRC channels, and collecting scripts from other hackers. The tone is playful, emphasizing the absurdity of some of the actions while also highlighting the culture of hacking. The second part shifts focus to becoming a ueberadmin, or a security expert, providing practical advice on securing systems against uebercrackers. It emphasizes the importance of understanding Unix, applying patches, and setting up firewalls to protect against intrusions. The article concludes with a call for better communication between security experts and vendors to improve overall internet security.
historical_context: This article reflects the hacker culture of the early 1990s, a time when the internet was becoming more accessible, and the need for security was becoming increasingly apparent. It captures the playful yet serious nature of the hacking community and the emerging dialogue around cybersecurity.
target_audience: Hackers, security professionals, and anyone interested in the history of hacking culture.
